questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of an oozing, red area above the left ankle. She does not recall any trauma to the lower extremity. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and ulcerative colitis. She had a myocardial infarction 2 years ago and a stroke 7 years ago. She has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 48 years and drinks 2 alcoholic beverages daily. Current medications include warfarin, metformin, aspirin, atorvastatin, carvedilol, and mesalamine. She is 165 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 67 kg (148 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 135/90 mm Hg. Examination shows yellow-brown spots and dilated tortuous veins over the lower extremities. The feet and the left calf are edematous. Femoral, popliteal, and pedal pulses are palpable bilaterally. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) painless, shallow, exudative ulcer surrounded by granulation tissue above the medial left ankle. There is slight drooping of the right side of the face. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ulcer?

choices.text: Vasculitis of small and medium-sized vessels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased arterial blood flow due to peripheral arterial disease (PAD) may lead to arterial ulcers. These typically painful ulcers are commonly located on the lateral surface of the ankle and the tips of the digits. This patient has many risk factors for arterial disease (stroke, myocardial infarction, smoking, type 2 diabetes mellitus), but does not have other manifestations of PAD like pallor and atrophy of the extremities or claudication. Additionally, she has a normal pulse status, making this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Photograph of left foot

Numerous ulcers are visible on this patient's foot.

This appearance is suggestive of ischemic ulcers in peripheral arterial disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Peripheral neuropathy (perhaps due to diabetes mellitus) often leads to neuropathic foot ulcers, commonly occurring on the bottom of the foot at sites of undetected injury or pressure. While this patient does have diabetes, her ulcer does not fit the typical description of a neuropathic ulcer.

C) INCORRECT:

Neutrophilic dermatosis (pyoderma gangrenosum) is a condition that causes deep ulcers, usually on the legs. This patient has ulcerative colitis, which is a risk factor of pyoderma gangrenosum, but the lesion generally begins as a small papule at the location of prior trauma (pathergy) and may progress to a large necrotic wound. It is not typically associated with edema and the skin changes seen in this patient.
Image Description:

A purulent ulcerative lesion with central necrosis and erythematous borders is visible on this patient's shin. The surrounding tissue appears to be swollen.

These findings are consistent with pyoderma gangrenosum, which most commonly affects the lower extremities.

D) CORRECT:

Chronic venous insufficiency often leads to venous ulcers or mixed ulcers, classically appearing just above the medial ankle and associated with skin changes and unilateral edema. The location of this patient's ulcer, as well as the accompanying varicosity, skin color changes, and lower extremity edema make venous insufficiency the most likely primary etiology of this ulcer. This ulcer is likely a mixed ulcer because of this patient's cardiovascular history, diabetes, and smoking.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic pressure may lead to a pressure ulcer. Pressure ulcers typically occur in immobilized patients and present as a painful loss of skin and subcutaneous tissue (e.g., over the sacrum, heel, or occiput). Diabetes, smoking, and cardiovascular disease, as seen in this patient, are also risk factors. The location of this patient's ulcer as well as the fact that she is ambulatory make a pressure ulcer unlikely.
Image Description:

A decubitus ulcer with loss of all skin layers and subcutaneous involvement is visible to the right of the intergluteal cleft.

F) INCORRECT:

Warfarin-induced skin necrosis is a subtype of drug-induced microvascular occlusion. It is caused by warfarin initially causing a procoagulable state, typically 3–5 days after initiating therapy. It manifests with pain and redness and may lead to hemorrhagic bullae and eventual necrosis. This condition is not associated with slowly progressive chronic skin changes as described in this patient, who has been taking warfarin for a longer period.

G) INCORRECT:

Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger disease) is a recurring progressive vasculitis of small and medium-sized vessels of the hands and feet that is strongly associated with smoking tobacco and typically affects men. While this patient is a smoker, she does not have other symptoms of arterial insufficiency (claudication, ischemic ulcers at the toe tips and lateral ankle), making this diagnosis unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient has risk factors for several types of lower extremity ulcerations. The key findings in this patient are edema, yellow-brown spots, and dilated tortuous veins in the lower extremities.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of swelling in her legs for the past 2 months. She has noticed that her legs gradually swell up throughout the day. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include lisinopril and metformin. She works as a waitress at a local diner. Her father died of liver cancer at the age of 61 years. She drinks one to two glasses of wine daily and occasionally more on weekends. She does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows 1+ pitting edema in both lower extremities up to the level of the calves with relative sparing of the feet. There are several dilated, compressible tortuous veins measuring 4–5 mm over both lower extremities, and multiple excoriation marks are noted over both ankles. There is a 2 x 2-cm ulcer with a shallow base and irregular edges over the medial surface of the left ankle. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, gallops, or rubs. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no organomegaly. Serum glucose, urea nitrogen, creatinine, D-dimer concentrations, and results of liver function tests are within the reference ranges. The ankle-brachial index is 1.1 bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sclerotherapy, which is a form of vein ablation therapy (VAT), is a treatment option for varicose veins. However, endovenous thermal ablation is preferred over sclerotherapy because of lower complication rates. Furthermore, another step is required before proceeding with VAT.

B) INCORRECT:

Antiplatelet (e.g., clopidogrel) or vasodilator (e.g., cilostazol) therapy is not effective in the management of CVD. These drugs are primarily used in the management of peripheral artery disease (PAD), which can cause lower limb ulcers but such ulcers typically have regular margins and a punched-out appearance and occur over pressure points (e.g., tips of toes, lateral malleolus). Furthermore, PAD causes pale, shiny, cold, hairless skin on the lower extremities rather than edema and dermatitis and the normal ankle-brachial index (1.0–1.4) makes PAD extremely unlikely.

C) CORRECT:

Current guidelines recommend that all patients suspected to have CVD should undergo duplex ultrasonography before any treatment. The goal is to identify whether the patient has a correctable cause of venous reflux (e.g., reflux in the superficial venous system), and to plan for an interventional procedure (e.g., by identifying the superficial, deep, and perforator vein sites) if the patient qualifies for such a procedure.

An initial trial of compression therapy is appropriate for patients with mild CVD (i.e., varicose veins or edema only) without a correctable cause, and pregnant patients with CVD. A patient with advanced CVD, as seen here, or a correctable cause of venous reflux should undergo endovenous thermal ablation as long as there are no contraindications to the procedure (e.g., deep vein thrombosis, peripheral artery disease). All patients with CVD should be counseled on lifestyle changes to improve venous return (e.g., daily exercise, frequent elevation of the legs, avoidance of long periods of standing and sitting).

D) INCORRECT:

Compression therapy (e.g., with compression stockings) provides symptomatic relief in patients with CVD. An initial trial of compression therapy is appropriate for patients with mild CVD (i.e., varicose veins or edema only) without a correctable cause, and pregnant patients with CVD. This patient has advanced CVD, for which a different treatment is indicated. Regardless of the severity, current guidelines recommend that any form of treatment should be preceded by another step.

E) INCORRECT:

For patients with CVD, studies such as venography or venous plethysmography are not routinely recommended. These studies are only considered if the initial imaging modality is inconclusive or in specific circumstances (e.g., surgical planning for CVD due to intraabdominal venous obstruction).
questions.hint: Lower extremity edema with relative sparing of the feet and dilated tortuous veins > 3 mm in diameter (varicose veins) in the absence of other systemic findings (e.g., pulmonary crackles, jugular venous distention) strongly suggests chronic venous disease (CVD), for which this patient's age, sex, and job that involves prolonged standing are risk factors. The presence of certain skin changes such as pruritic dermatitis or a venous ulcer indicates advanced CVD.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of dull, persistent pain and swelling of her right leg. The pain is worse at the end of the day and is relieved by walking or elevating her feet. Two years ago, she developed acute deep vein thrombosis in her right calf after a long flight, which was treated with anticoagulants for 6 months. Physical examination shows 2+ pitting edema of her right leg. The skin around the right ankle shows a reddish-brown discoloration and multiple telangiectasias. She has dilated varicose veins in the right leg. Which of the following is most likely to establish the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Computed tomography scan with contrast of the lower extremities is used to evaluate patients for deep infections (e.g., abscesses), malignancy, or injury in the lower extremities. It is not used to evaluate for CVI.

B) INCORRECT:

Nerve conduction studies are used to evaluate the function of the peripheral nervous system. They are particularly critical for diagnosing polyneuropathies (e.g., due to chronic diabetes mellitus). Although polyneuropathy can manifest with asymmetric or unilateral pain, which is seen in this patient, the pain usually takes the form of a buzzing or tingling sensation, not a dull ache. Moreover, polyneuropathy would not cause the edema and telangiectasias seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The D-dimer assay is a nonspecific test that is indicated for patients with a low pretest probability of acute DVT to rule out an acute thrombotic event. The test has a high negative predictive value (> 95%); therefore, a negative test result effectively rules out the presence of a DVT or a pulmonary embolism.

D) INCORRECT:

The ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) is used to screen for peripheral arterial disease (PAD) in patients who present with lower limb pain that suggests claudication pain (i.e., pain on walking that is relieved with rest). This patient's pain improves with walking, making PAD an unlikely cause of her symptoms. Her symptoms are consistent with CVI, which cannot be evaluated with ABPI.

E) CORRECT:

Duplex ultrasonography (compression ultrasonography) is the first-line investigation in patients with features suggestive of CVI, as seen here. Evidence of venous reflux on duplex ultrasonography confirms the diagnosis of CVI. Duplex ultrasonography can help determine the course of treatment by identifying which valves are incompetent and assessing the patency of the previously thrombosed deep veins.
questions.hint: This patient's unilateral chronic dull pain, edema, dilated veins in the lower extremity, and history of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) suggest chronic venous insufficiency (CVI).

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of itching of both legs. She also has swelling and dull pain that are worse at the end of the day and more severe in her right leg. She has hyperthyroidism, asthma, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Four years ago, she had basal cell carcinoma of the face that was treated with Mohs surgery. Current medications include methimazole, albuterol, and insulin. She has smoked 3–4 cigarettes a day for the past 29 years. She goes to a local sauna twice a week. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 124/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows light skin with diffuse freckles. There is 2+ pitting edema of the right leg and 1+ pitting edema of the left leg. There is diffuse reddish-brown discoloration and significant scaling extending from the ankle to the mid-thigh bilaterally. Pedal pulses and sensation are intact bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Breach of skin barrier by dermatophyte
Congenital abnormality of the lymphatic system
Breach of skin barrier by bacteria

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Type IV hypersensitivity reaction is a delayed T-cell response to an antigen (e.g., contact dermatitis) that occurs 12–48 hours after exposure. The patient has had a 3-month history of pruritus and has no recent history of new exposures. In addition, type IV hypersensitivity reactions do not cause stasis dermatitis.

B) CORRECT:

Venous valve incompetence is the most common cause of chronic venous insufficiency, which can manifest with leg pain, edema, and stasis dermatitis, as seen in this patient. As venous pressure rises (due to incompetent venous valves), the veins become varicose and leak inflammatory factors into the interstitium, leading to edema, inflammation, and pruritus.

C) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin (SCC) is characterized by malignant proliferation of epidermal keratinocytes. This patient has a history of skin cancer and has light skin, which is a risk factor for SCC. However, SCC presents as a painless, slow-growing ulcerated lesion and would not lead to diffuse discoloration, edema, or stasis dermatitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Pretibial myxedema is a finding seen in Graves disease characterized by dermal accumulation of glycosaminoglycans on the anterior or lateral surfaces of the legs due to stimulation of connective tissue cells that express TSH receptors. Unlike the edema seen in this patient, pretibial myxedema is characterized as nonpitting.

E) INCORRECT:

Tinea pedis is an infection that results from breach of the skin barrier by dermatophytes. Although the patient has risk factors for tinea pedis (local sauna), this condition affects the sole of the foot and the space between the toes. Tinea pedis would not cause pitting edema or other symptoms of stasis dermatitis.

F) INCORRECT:

Lymphedema can occur due to a congenital abnormality of the lymphatic system. However, such lymphedema typically manifests in childhood and is not pruritic. Acquired lymphedema can occur later in life due to malignancy, surgery, or radiation therapy (none of which this patient had).

G) INCORRECT:

Cellulitis is an infection that results from breach of the skin barrier by bacteria. Although cellulitis can present with the same local symptoms as stasis dermatitis, it would also be accompanied by fevers or chills. Bilateral cellulitis is very rare.
questions.hint: Skin discoloration and a pruritic, scaly rash in a patient with a long history of bilateral dull leg pain and edema that are worse at the end of the day is consistent with stasis dermatitis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of a rash on her ankles with intermittent itching. After the rash developed, she started applying a new scented lotion to her legs daily. She works as a cashier at a grocery store. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin and enalapril. Examination shows enlarged superficial veins of the right lower extremity and red-brown discoloration with indistinct margins over the medial ankles. There is 1+ edema in the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s skin findings?

choices.text: Bacterial spread through the superficial dermis
Contact of antigen with pre-sensitized T lymphocytes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bacterial spread through the superficial dermis and lymphatics is the underlying cause of erysipelas, which typically results in lower extremity erythema and edema and is more common in individuals with diabetes mellitus (due to impaired neutrophil function from hyperglycemia and diabetic neuropathy). However, skin lesions of erysipelas are usually well-demarcated, unilateral, nonpruritic, and associated with systemic manifestations (e.g., fever and chills).
Image Description:

Sharply demarcated, swollen, erythematous lesion with raised borders on the lower leg. Additionally, pitting edema is seen in the areas where the sock has applied pressure to the underlying tissue.

B) INCORRECT:

Contact of antigen with pre-sensitized T lymphocytes is the underlying mechanism of allergic contact dermatitis, which usually manifests with a pruritic, erythematous rash with indistinct margins. Products that contain fragrance are common contact allergens. However, this patient's rash preceded her use of a new lotion. Additionally, allergic contact dermatitis typically only causes edema in areas that have thin skin (e.g., the lips and eyelids) and does not result in varicose veins.
Image Description:

Upper body of a man presenting with a severely pruritic rash after getting a henna tattoo on the right arm

An erythematous papulovesicular rash is visible over the chest and arms. The rash is most severe around the henna tattoo, which appears markedly erythematous.

This is the typical appearance of allergic contact dermatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Intracellular accumulation of sorbitol is involved in the pathogenesis of diabetic neuropathy, a condition that causes abnormal sensation in the lower extremities in patients with diabetes. Sorbitol accumulates in cells that lack sorbitol dehydrogenase (e.g., Schwann cells), which leads to osmotic damage. However, diabetic neuropathy does not cause edema, varicose veins, or red-brown discoloration.

D) INCORRECT:

Insufficient arterial tissue perfusion can cause ischemic ulcers, which often manifest at sites of focal pressure such as the medial malleoli. These ulcers develop in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD), which is associated with advanced age, diabetes, and hypertension. However, they are typically painful and well-demarcated. Additionally, this patient does not have other common symptoms of PAD such as claudication, hair loss on the leg, or nail changes.

E) INCORRECT:

Tinea pedis, a dermatophyte infection, most commonly develops on the feet and causes a pruritic, scaly rash. Erythema can also occur but is less common. Tinea pedis typically affects the digital interspaces and soles of the feet (not the medial ankles) and is not associated with edema or varicose veins.
Image Description:

Plantar view of the left foot

There is skin peeling in the region of the forefoot with a blistered appearance. The erythematous base appears dry and scaly.

These findings are characteristic of tinea pedis.

F) CORRECT:

Dermal deposition of hemosiderin is a key feature of stasis dermatitis. Elevated venous pressures from chronic venous disease result in red blood cell breakdown, which leads to hemosiderin production. Hemosiderin penetrates defective capillaries and accumulates in the dermis, which causes a pruritic, red-brown rash, as seen in this patient. The medial ankles are the most frequently involved site.
Image Description:

Yellow-brown skin discoloration (hemosiderin deposition) and edema is present. A varicose vein can be seen on the anterior aspect of the right leg below the knee.

These changes are consistent with CEAP class 4 venous insufficiency.
questions.hint: This woman has a pruritic, red-brown rash over the medial ankles, varicose veins, and bilateral lower extremity edema. Her occupation likely requires her to stand for prolonged periods. These findings suggest stasis dermatitis due to chronic venous disease.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with hypertension comes to the physician because of swelling and pain in both legs for the past year. The symptoms are worse at night and improve in the morning. Current medications include losartan and metoprolol. Her temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 67/min, and blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. Examination shows normal heart sounds; there is no jugular venous distention. Her abdomen is soft and the liver edge is not palpable. Examination of the lower extremities shows bilateral pitting edema and prominent superficial veins. The skin is warm and there is reddish-brown discoloration of both ankles. Laboratory studies show a normal serum creatinine and normal urinalysis. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased platelet aggregation is involved in the pathophysiology of deep venous thrombosis, which also classically manifests with lower extremity swelling and pain. However, symptoms of DVT are typically acute in onset and unilateral; the bilateral, chronic nature of this patient's symptoms makes DVT unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased lymphatic flow can cause an accumulation of filtered lymph fluid in the interstitium, which manifests as lymphedema. This patient's chronic skin changes and lack of risk factors for lymphedema (radiation therapy, surgery, tumor obstruction) suggest a different underlying mechanism.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased plasma oncotic pressure is typically seen in diseases that cause hypoproteinemia, such as nephrotic syndrome, malnutrition, and/or liver cirrhosis. While low oncotic pressure can lead to bilateral peripheral edema, this patient does not have any risk factors or exam findings (e.g., hepatomegaly, proteinuria) consistent with renal or liver disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased arteriolar resistance can be caused by medications that induce vascular smooth muscle relaxation, such as dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (e.g., amlodipine). Patients on dihydropyridines can also present with pitting edema. However, this patient is not taking dihydropyridines, and neither losartan nor metoprolol cause decreased arteriolar resistance.

E) CORRECT:

A female patient of advanced age with bilateral leg swelling, skin discoloration, and pain most likely has chronic venous insufficiency and varicose veins. In CVI, defective venous valve leaflets result in reflux of venous blood back into the periphery, leading to increased venous pressure (hydrostatic pressure) and subsequent extravasation of venous blood into the interstitium. Plasma proteins in the interstitium in turn cause edema and tissue hypoperfusion, which results in inflammation, atrophy, and possibly ulcer formation.
Image Description:

Longitudinal section of a vein with valves

Valves are flaps lined by intima that allow blood to flow in the direction of the heart (left illustration) but prevent the reflux of blood to the periphery (right illustration). If blood flows backward, the flaps are filled with blood, press against each other, and close the lumen of the vein.

F) INCORRECT:

Increased capillary permeability is seen in patients with systemic inflammation and/or distributive shock (e.g., from anaphylaxis or sepsis). Extravasation of plasma proteins through the permeable capillary walls causes edema. This patient is afebrile, not tachycardic or hypotensive, and has no symptoms to suggest infection or inflammation. Her chronic skin changes suggest a different underlying cause of her symptoms.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has varicose veins, a condition that can be problematic for patients with occupations that require prolonged standing.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 6-month history of pain and swelling of both legs. The symptoms are worst at the end of the day and are associated with itching of the overlying skin. Physical examination shows bilateral pitting ankle edema. An image of one of the ankles is shown. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?

choices.text: Osmotic injury to the peripheral nerves

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thrombosis of a deep vein is associated with increased age, a history of smoking, inherited thrombophilias, OCP use, and malignancy. While superficial thrombophlebitis and thrombosis are common in CVI, deep vein thrombosis is rare.

B) INCORRECT:

Sepsis with gram-positive bacteria (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus, Group A streptococcus) can occur following skin or soft tissue infections (e.g., cellulitis, necrotizing fasciitis), which would manifest with pain and swelling in the affected region. However, the symptoms of skin or subcutaneous tissue infection would occur acutely, unlike this patient who had symptoms for the past 6 months, and erythema would be evident on inspection. Although CVI is itself a risk factor for developing cellulitis, a different complication of CVI is much more likely than sepsis.

C) INCORRECT:

Malignant transformation of lymphatic endothelium causes lymphangiosarcoma, a rare malignancy that is due to chronic lymphedema rather than CVI. While squamous cell cancer can be seen in some cases of CVI at the site of the chronic ulcer, lymphangiosarcoma would not be seen.

D) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of biliverdin in the epidermis is responsible for the hyperpigmentation seen following subcutaneous hematoma formation. However, in CVI, hyperpigmentation is due to the dermal deposition of hemosiderin, which occurs over time as extravasated RBCs are broken down.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with untreated diabetes mellitus (DM) are at increased risk of osmotic injury to the peripheral nerves (diabetic neuropathy). Patients with untreated DM often develop pathologies in the lower extremities (e.g., skin and soft tissue infections, ischemic or neuropathic ulcers) but the dilated veins seen in the photograph suggest CVI, which does not result in peripheral nerve injury.
Image Description:

Left foot of a patient with diabetes and a history of having stepped on a nail

The big toe appears severely swollen and erythematous with a large ulcer on the medial side of the first metatarsophalangeal joint and a second ulcer more distally. Cellulitis extends to the black line. HbA1c of > 10% confirmed the diagnosis of diabetic foot infection.

F) CORRECT:

In CVI defective venous valve leaflets lead to reflux of venous blood back into the periphery, resulting in increased venous pressure (hydrostatic pressure) and subsequent extravasation of venous blood into the interstitium. Plasma proteins in the interstitium, in turn, cause edema and tissue hypoperfusion, which results in stasis dermatitis, lipodermatosclerosis, and, in some cases, ulcer formation. Venous ulcers tend to occur over the shin and medial malleolus and are shallow, tender, and surrounded by hyperpigmented skin.
Image Description:

Medial aspect of the right foot

An ulcer with surrounding erythema is visible on the medial malleolus of the right foot.

These findings are characteristic of venous ulcer secondary to chronic venous insufficiency.
questions.hint: The varicose veins, brown skin discoloration, and corona phlebectatica in this patient are signs of chronic venous insufficiency (CVI).

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, comes to the physician because of left ankle swelling for 2 months. She notes that the swelling is present throughout the day and decreases when she goes to sleep. One year ago, she had an episode of deep venous thrombosis after the delivery of her third child. Her prepregnancy BMI was 34 kg/m2. Examination shows distended, tortuous veins in the legs bilaterally and pitting edema of the left ankle. There are erythematous scaling patches on the medial side of the left ankle. Duplex ultrasonography is performed. Which of the following directions of blood flow would most likely confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Anterior tibial vein to popliteal vein
Popliteal vein to small saphenous vein
Femoral vein to external iliac vein
Great saphenous vein to femoral vein
Dorsal venous arch to great saphenous vein

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Venous blood flowing from the anterior tibial vein to the popliteal vein indicates normal blood flow from a peripheral deep vein to a deep vein. Chronic venous disease, however, is characterized by retrograde blood flow, or venous reflux from the deep veins into the superficial veins.

B) CORRECT:

Venous blood flowing from the deep popliteal vein to the superficial small saphenous vein indicates retrograde blood flow and confirms the diagnosis of chronic venous disease. Normally, the small saphenous vein would arise from the dorsal venous arch and drain into the popliteal vein at the saphenopopliteal junction. In a patient with chronic venous disease, however, incompetence of the venous valves caused by elevated venous pressure (e.g., due to pregnancy, increased BMI, prior thrombosis) leads to blood reflux from deep into superficial veins. This results in the formation of varicose veins, and ultimately edema and skin changes (e.g., stasis dermatitis), as seen in this patient. First-line treatment consists of conservative measures such as leg elevation, compression therapy, and application of topical dermatologic agents.
Image Description:

The superficial veins are depicted in the right leg:
- Great saphenous vein: arises from the medial end of the dorsal venous arch, courses in front of the medial malleolus, up the medial aspect of the leg, behind the medial border of the patella, and up the medial aspect of the thigh. It terminates by draining into the femoral vein at the saphenofemoral junction, which is typically located ~4 cm inferolateral to the pubic tubercle.
- Short saphenous vein: arises from the lateral end of the dorsal venous arch, courses behind the lateral malleolus, and up the posterior aspect of the leg. It terminates by draining into the popliteal vein at the saphenopopliteal junction, which usually lies in the popliteal fossa (not shown here).

The deep veins are depicted in the left leg:
- Peripheral deep veins: anterior tibial, posterior tibial, and fibular (peroneal) veins
- Popliteal vein: formed by the confluence of the peripheral deep veins
- Femoral vein: continuation of the popliteal vein. It begins at the adductor hiatus and accompanies the femoral artery throughout its course. The deep femoral vein (profunda femoris) is the main tributary of the femoral vein.
- External iliac vein: continuation of the femoral vein. It begins behind the inguinal ligament and drains into the common iliac vein.

C) INCORRECT:

Venous blood flowing from the femoral vein to the external iliac vein indicates normal blood flow from a deep vein to a proximal deep vein. Chronic venous disease, however, is characterized by retrograde blood flow, or venous reflux from the deep veins into the superficial veins.

D) INCORRECT:

Venous blood flowing from the great saphenous vein to the femoral vein indicates normal blood flow from a superficial to a deep vein. Chronic venous disease, however, is characterized by retrograde blood flow, or venous reflux from the deep veins into the superficial veins.

E) INCORRECT:

The dorsal venous arch is a superficial vein that gives rise to the great saphenous vein and small saphenous vein, which are superficial veins that originate from the medial and lateral sides of the dorsal venous arch, respectively. Therefore, blood normally flows from the dorsal venous arch to the great saphenous vein. Chronic venous disease, however, is characterized by retrograde blood flow, or venous reflux from the deep veins into the superficial veins.
questions.hint: Distended and tortuous veins in both legs, ankle edema, and skin changes on the medial ankle indicate chronic venous disease.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 34 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of left leg swelling for 5 weeks. She notes that the swelling increases with prolonged standing and decreases with leg elevation. She works as a high school librarian. She has no history of serious illness. Her only medications are a multivitamin and a fish-oil supplement. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her father died from an ischemic stroke at 56 years old. She is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 109 kg (240 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows tortuous dilated vessels posterior to the medial malleoli and on the medial side of the calves. There is mild bilateral pitting edema. Imaging of the left lower leg is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Corkscrew collaterals in the posterior tibial artery
Increased peak systolic velocity in the femoral artery
Bidirectional blood flow in the great saphenous vein
Intraluminal thrombus in the popliteal vein

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Corkscrew-shaped collateral vessels around an occlusion in the posterior tibial artery would be seen on arteriography in patients with thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO). TAO is a vasculitic disease and affects both the arteries and veins, but this patient does not present with symptoms of arterial disease such as claudication or Raynaud phenomenon. Additionally, TAO most commonly manifests in young, male smokers, while this patient is a female with no history of smoking.
Image Description:

Angiography (intraoperative; lower leg) of a patient with thromboangiitis obliterans

The tibial and peroneal arteries are occluded and compensatory corkscrew collaterals (green overlay) have developed.

Corkscrew collaterals represent the dilated vasa vasorum of occluded arteries. They can be seen in thromboangiitis obliterans and several other vasculitides.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased peak systolic velocity due to stenosis in the femoral artery would be seen on Doppler ultrasonography in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD). This patient's family history of vascular disease (i.e., her father died due to an ischemic stroke at a young age) is a risk factor for PAD, but she does not present with typical features of arterial disease such as intermittent claudication, rest pain, or ischemic ulcers. Additionally, PAD is not associated with varicose veins.

C) CORRECT:

Bidirectional blood flow in the great saphenous vein on duplex ultrasonography, rather than the normal unilateral blood flow from the superficial to the deep system, is diagnostic of chronic venous insufficiency. Risk factors for chronic venous disease in this patient include female sex, family history of vascular disease (her father died from an ischemic stroke at a young age), pregnancy, obesity, and prolonged standing (i.e., work as a high school librarian). Elevated venous pressure leads to the incompetence of venous valves, causing reflux of blood into superficial veins, resulting in further elevation of venous pressure and the formation of varicose veins. Edema that worsens with standing and improves with leg elevation indicates progression of her venous disease due to damage to the capillary basement membrane. If this patient's chronic venous insufficiency remains untreated, she may develop chronic venous stasis ulcers.

Conservative measures for chronic venous disease include compression therapy with compression stockings, frequent elevation of the legs, physical therapy, manual lymphatic drainage, and avoidance of heat and long periods of standing or sitting with bent legs.

- Great saphenous vein: arises from the medial end of the dorsal venous arch, courses in front of the medial malleolus, up the medial aspect of the leg, behind the medial border of the patella, and up the medial aspect of the thigh. It terminates by draining into the femoral vein at the saphenofemoral junction, which is typically located ~ 4 cm inferolateral to the pubic tubercle.
- Small saphenous vein: arises from the lateral end of the dorsal venous arch, courses behind the lateral malleolus, and up the posteroior aspect of the leg. It terminates by draining into the popliteal vein at the saphenopopliteal junction, which usually lies in the popliteal fossa (not shown here).

The deep veins are depicted in the left leg
- Peripheral deep veins: anterior tibial, posterior tibial, and fibular (peroneal) veins
- Popliteal vein: formed by the confluence of the peripheral deep veins.
- Femoral vein: is the continuation of the popliteal vein. It begins at the adductor hiatus and accompanies the femoral artery throughout its course. The deep femoral vein (profunda femoris) is the main tributary of the femoral vein.
- External iliac vein: continuation of the femoral vein. It begins behind the inguinal ligament and drains into the common iliac vein.

An intraluminal thrombus in the popliteal vein would be seen on duplex ultrasonography in patients with a deep venous thrombosis (DVT) of the popliteal vein. Additional symptoms, including unilateral pain, warmth, erythema, and tenderness, would be expected in a patient presenting with a DVT.

E) INCORRECT:

A thickened, noncompressible sural vein seen on duplex ultrasonography indicates superficial thrombophlebitis. While varicose veins are a risk factor for superficial thrombophlebitis, additional symptoms, including pain, tenderness, induration, and erythema overlying a superficial vein (commonly with a palpable cord), would be expected. Additionally, uncomplicated superficial thrombophlebitis typically does not manifest with leg swelling that worsens with prolonged standing and decreases with leg elevation.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 77 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: clinic
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “My leg hurts.”
History of Present Illness:


1-month history of pain in the left leg

pain worsens with walking and is relieved with elevation

associated symptoms include swelling and pruritis

Past Medical History:

hypertension
type 2 diabetes mellitus

deep vein thrombosis in left lower extremity following hip surgery one year ago, treated with three months of apixaban

Medications:

amlodipine
metformin
dulaglutide

Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:

mother: deceased at age 76 years from breast cancer
father: deceased at age 68 years due to complications from diabetes mellitus

Psychosocial History:

does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs
has three pet cats; volunteers at an animal rescue shelter 
works part-time as a gardener

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


36.0 °C(96.8 °F)
80/min
14/min
120/76 mm Hg
-
160 cm(5 ft 3 in)
65 kg(143 lb)
25.3 kg/m2




Appearance: sitting in a chair; comfortable
HEENT: PERRL; ocular movements are intact
Neck: no jugular venous distention
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation bilaterally
Cardiac: regular rate and rhythm; no murmurs
Abdominal: nondistended; soft and nontender
Extremities: 2+ edema that extends to the middle of the left shin; red-brown discoloration of the medial left ankle with induration; shallow ulceration superior to medial left ankle with irregular borders; visible paraplantar varicose veins; examination of right lower extremity is normal

Neurologic: alert; cranial nerves intact


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has risk factors for primary venous insufficiency (e.g., female sex, older age), which can manifest with pain, pruritus, edema, skin changes, varicose veins, and ulcers, symptoms are typically bilateral. This patient's history of deep vein thrombosis makes a secondary cause of venous insufficiency more likely.

B) CORRECT:

Postthrombotic syndrome is a complication after deep vein thrombosis (DVT) that manifests unilaterally in the affected extremity and is characterized by chronic venous insufficiency. Features of postthrombotic syndrome include pain, swelling, pruritus, varicose veins, edema, and trophic skin changes. Symptoms are typically relieved by elevation of the legs. Venous ulcers are a complication of advanced posthrombotic syndrome and manifest as shallow lesions with irregular borders that typically cause pruritus and mild pain. Patients with mild disease are treated with lifestyle modifications (e.g., leg elevation) and compression therapy (e.g., compression stockings). Interventional procedures (e.g., endovenous thermal ablation) are used when conservative management with compression therapy fails or when complications (e.g., ulceration, trophic skin changes) are present.

C) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has risk factors for peripheral artery disease (PAD) such as hypertension and diabetes, she does not have typical manifestations like pallor, atrophy, or intermittent claudication. Additionally, an arterial ulcer is a painful, punched-out wound with well-defined borders that typically affects the toes, shins, or other pressure points. Moreover, pain in PAD is relieved by lowering rather than elevating the affected limb.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient works as a gardener and could have been exposed through an open wound to Sporothrix schenckii, a dimorphic fungus that feeds on decaying vegetation. This infection manifests with pustules, ulcers, ascending lymphangitis, and nodules along draining lymphatics rather than venous ulcers.

E) INCORRECT:

Pasteurella multocida is a gram-negative coccobacillus that can be transmitted through the oropharynx of animals (especially cats and dogs). Infection causes symptoms consistent with cellulitis (erythema, edema, warmth, tenderness) and does not typically cause ulceration.
questions.hint: This patient presents with an ulcer just above the ankle (in the Gaiter region), which is a typical location for venous ulcers.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and congestive heart failure that is currently well compensated presents with gradually progressive redness in her legs. She has a long history of lower-leg swelling that worsens during the day and improves slightly overnight. The discolored areas are sometimes itchy and sometimes mildly uncomfortable.
On examination, the patient appears well and is afebrile. There is 3+ nontender pitting edema below the knees and a symmetric discoloration of both lower legs (figure). There is no lymphadenopathy.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erythema nodosum is a hypersensitivity reaction that causes painful, erythematous subcutaneous nodules on the anterior shins.

B) CORRECT:

Stasis dermatitis most commonly occurs in the setting of chronic venous insufficiency and is characterized by bilateral lower-leg swelling and erythema. In long-standing cases, the legs become hyperpigmented in the edematous areas as a result of erythrocyte extravasation leading to hemosiderin deposition. Patients often have features of venous insufficiency that cause stasis, such as varicose veins and brawny hyperpigmentation on the medial aspects of the ankles. Blistering and ulceration can occur, but there should be no systemic features, such as fever, elevated leukocyte count, or lymphadenopathy.

Recognizing the features of stasis dermatitis and distinguishing them from cellulitis is critical.

Key learning point: Bilateral lower-leg erythema and hyperpigmentation in an older patient with a history of chronic leg edema points to a diagnosis of stasis dermatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Cellulitis is characterized by well-demarcated erythema and associated edema, tenderness or pain of the involved area, and fever. Its onset is usually rapid, and it is almost always unilateral.

D) INCORRECT:

Contact dermatitis is characterized by a well-demarcated pruritic red rash caused by topically applied therapies. Contact dermatitis is often vesicular and weepy in the acute stages and scaly in chronic, long-standing cases. Contact dermatitis can be symmetric, well demarcated, bilateral, and red, but significant pitting edema would be unusual unless contact dermatitis and stasis dermatitis were coexistent, which does happen with some frequency.

E) INCORRECT:

Psoriasis presents as well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with overlying silvery white scale. Although psoriasis can be found on the lower legs, the clinical picture would not typically include pitting edema in a bilateral symmetric location (unless the two conditions overlapped, which can occur).

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents as a new patient for evaluation of redness and itching that he has had on his legs intermittently for many months. He recently saw a vascular surgeon, who performed ankle-brachial index testing and found normal results.
He has a history of congestive heart failure with a left ventricular ejection fraction of 40%. He has no history of deep-vein thrombosis, kidney disease, or liver dysfunction. His current daily medications include metoprolol, simvastatin, lisinopril, furosemide, and aspirin 81 mg.
On physical examination, he appears to be comfortable and in no distress. He has a temperature of 37.0°C, a heart rate of 72 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 125/85 mm Hg, and a BMI of 29. Cardiac examination reveals a jugular venous pressure of 10 cm of water, a regular heart rate and rhythm with a nondisplaced point of maximal impulse, and no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Lung examination is clear. Vascular examination demonstrates normal palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses with warm, well-perfused feet and good capillary refill.
Skin examination reveals inflamed erythematous skin on both lower extremities with accentuation at the ankles. There is underlying reddish-brown skin more proximally on the legs and within the more acutely inflamed areas (figure). There is only mild and proximal involvement of the tops of the feet.
Which one of the following topical therapies is most appropriate for this patient’s skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical nitroglycerin has no role in the management of stasis dermatitis. It is occasionally used to relieve pain and ulceration due to cutaneous vasospasm, but that is not relevant in the clinical context of this particular case.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical bacitracin can lead to allergic reactions, and this patient has no sign of a bacterial skin infection such as fissures, erosions, or purulent drainage.

C) INCORRECT:

Silver sulfadiazine is often used for gram-negative skin infections and extremity ulcers. It is not indicated in a patient who has no evidence of infection or ulceration.

D) INCORRECT:

Given this patient’s history and physical findings, he has no indication for a topical antifungal such as ketoconazole. Notably, both stasis dermatitis and tinea pedis may be risk factors for lower-extremity infections, and it is reasonable to inspect the feet to confirm that the patient has no web-space maceration, scaling, or onychomycosis. If any of these findings are present, antifungal therapy may be beneficial.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s skin findings are consistent with an acute flare of stasis dermatitis, which usually manifests in the setting of chronic lower-extremity edema. Chronic edema leads to stasis dermatitis, a skin reaction characterized by erythema, xerosis, and scale in the areas of edematous tissue; it is not accompanied by fever or specific laboratory abnormalities and is often bilateral. Over time, a background speckled, peppered hyperpigmentation due to hemosiderin deposition from extravasated red blood cells accumulates, resulting in a rust color. Stasis dermatitis can be associated with an intermittent acute eczematous dermatitis that is characterized by inflamed, red, weepy, pruritic skin. Over time, the affected areas of skin can develop scaling, lichenification, and marked hyperpigmentation and may break down and ulcerate. The redness on the legs is often mistaken for cellulitis, but cellulitis is typically acute, unilateral, and accompanied by fever, an elevated leukocyte count, or both.

The core problem in patients with stasis dermatitis is interstitial edema caused by either acute sources (e.g., obstruction related to deep-vein thrombosis) or chronic fluid backup (e.g., related to congestive heart failure, as in this patient). Management relies on optimization of total body fluid status, nutrition, calf-pump exercises, and supportive care. Mechanical compression stockings are also recommended, initially with 20–30 mm Hg of compression.

This patient presents with acutely inflamed stasis dermatitis characterized by erythema and pruritus. The appropriate management is a topical glucocorticoid, such as triamcinolone, to alleviate the pruritus and inflammation. The glucocorticoid can often be used for a short period (2 to 4 weeks), with intermittent therapy as necessary during acute flares of stasis dermatitis. An emollient may be used to keep the area moisturized when there is not an acute flare. Topical management of the acute inflammation is a short-term solution; long-term preventive care requires management of the edema as described above.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with congestive heart failure who presents with bilateral lower-extremity edema and erythema characterized by a reddish-brown discoloration of the skin is stasis dermatitis.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old woman reports that her calves have felt heavy, with a sensation of tingling and burning, for the past several months. The symptoms worsen at the end of the day and improve the next morning. The patient reports no skin changes, redness, shortness of breath, or chest pain. She has a history of hypertension, obesity (BMI, 43), sleep apnea, and one prior deep-vein thrombosis (in her left leg at age 65 after a long airplane ride).
Physical examination of her legs reveals the following (figure):
Duplex ultrasonography shows dilated compressible veins without evidence of great saphenous reflux.
What is the most appropriate next step in care for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Therapeutic anticoagulation has no role in the treatment of varicose veins but would be indicated in the setting of an acute deep-vein thrombosis (DVT). Prior DVT can be a risk factor for the development of varicose veins. However, the classic symptoms of an acute DVT include swelling, pain, warmth, and redness in the involved extremity. These symptoms do not wax and wane, and they tend to progress without appropriate treatment. Diagnosis should generally be confirmed with an imaging modality, such as ultrasound, before treatment is initiated.

B) INCORRECT:

More aggressive treatments for varicose veins (e.g., endovenous laser ablation) are typically recommended for patients who cannot adhere to or do not respond to conservative management.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms and findings on physical examination and ultrasonography are most consistent with varicose veins. The clinical presentation of this condition may vary, with symptoms including pain, burning, itching, leg aching, fatigue, and swelling. The symptoms are often worse at the end of the day, especially after prolonged periods of standing, and usually disappear when the patient sits and elevates their legs.

Although varicose veins may cause varying degrees of discomfort and cosmetic concern, the condition is rarely associated with significant medical complications. Conservative treatment options are considered first-line therapy by most clinicians and patients, are required by many payors to be used before interventional therapies will be covered, and should be advised in this case. These options include avoidance of prolonged standing and straining, elevation of the affected leg, exercise, external compression with compression stockings, loosening of restrictive clothing, medical therapy, modification of cardiovascular risk factors, reduction of peripheral edema, and weight loss.

More aggressive treatments include external laser treatment, injection sclerotherapy, endovenous interventions, and surgery. These treatments are typically recommended for patients who do not respond to compression therapy or who are unable to apply the compression stockings. In certain patients, proceeding straight to interventional therapies may be considered; this approach is typically recommended in cases where there is evidence of saphenous vein reflux (as most of the procedures target the saphenous vein primarily) or where the patient has severe symptoms or skin changes. However, this patient does not have evidence of saphenous vein reflux, and her symptoms are relatively mild; thus, conservative management is recommended as initial treatment.

Key learning point: Although varicose veins may cause varying degrees of discomfort or cosmetic concern, they are rarely associated with significant medical complications.

D) INCORRECT:

More aggressive treatments for varicose veins (e.g., surgery) are typically recommended for patients who cannot adhere to or do not respond to conservative management.

E) INCORRECT:

More aggressive treatments for varicose veins (e.g., injection sclerotherapy) are typically recommended for patients who cannot adhere to or do not respond to conservative management.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 34 weeks' gestation comes to the office because of left leg swelling for 5 weeks. She notes that the swelling increases with prolonged standing and decreases with leg elevation. She works as a high school librarian. She has no history of serious illness. Her only medications are a multivitamin and a fish-oil supplement. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 109 kg (240 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m2. Examination shows tortuous dilated vessels posterior to the medial malleoli and on the medial side of the calves and mild bilateral pitting edema. Imaging of the left lower leg is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Corkscrew collaterals in the posterior tibial artery
Increased peak systolic velocity in the femoral artery
Bidirectional blood flow in the great saphenous vein
Intraluminal thrombus in the popliteal vein

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

TAO is a vasculitic disease and affects both the arteries and veins, but this patient does not present with symptoms of arterial disease such as claudication or Raynaud phenomenon. Additionally, TAO most commonly manifests in young, male smokers, while this patient is a female with no history of smoking.
Image Description:

Angiography (intraoperative; lower leg) of a patient with thromboangiitis obliterans

The tibial and peroneal arteries are occluded and compensatory corkscrew collaterals (green overlay) have developed.

Corkscrew collaterals represent the dilated vasa vasorum of occluded arteries. They can be seen in thromboangiitis obliterans and several other vasculitides.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 6-month history of dull, persistent pain and swelling of her right leg. The pain is worse at the end of the day and is relieved by walking or elevating her feet. Two years ago, she developed acute deep vein thrombosis in her right calf after a long flight, which was treated with anticoagulants for 6 months. Physical examination shows 2+ pitting edema of her right leg. The skin around the right ankle shows a reddish-brown discoloration and multiple telangiectasias. She has dilated varicose veins in the right leg. Which of the following is most likely to establish the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Computed tomography scan with contrast of the lower extremities is used to evaluate patients for deep infections (e.g., abscesses), malignancy, or injury in the lower extremities. It is not used to evaluate for CVI.

B) INCORRECT:

Nerve conduction studies are used to evaluate the function of the peripheral nervous system. They are particularly critical for diagnosing polyneuropathies (e.g., due to chronic diabetes mellitus). Although polyneuropathy can manifest with asymmetric or unilateral pain, which is seen in this patient, the pain usually takes the form of a buzzing or tingling sensation, not a dull ache. Moreover, polyneuropathy would not cause the edema and telangiectasias seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The D-dimer assay is a nonspecific test that is indicated for patients with a low pretest probability of acute DVT to rule out an acute thrombotic event. The test has a high negative predictive value (> 95%); therefore, a negative test result effectively rules out the presence of a DVT or a pulmonary embolism.

D) INCORRECT:

The ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) is used to screen for peripheral arterial disease (PAD) in patients who present with lower limb pain that suggests claudication pain (i.e., pain on walking that is relieved with rest). This patient's pain improves with walking, making PAD an unlikely cause of her symptoms. Her symptoms are consistent with CVI, which cannot be evaluated with ABPI.

E) CORRECT:

Duplex ultrasonography (compression ultrasonography) is the first-line investigation in patients with features suggestive of CVI, as seen here. Evidence of venous reflux on duplex ultrasonography confirms the diagnosis of CVI. Duplex ultrasonography can help determine the course of treatment by identifying which valves are incompetent and assessing the patency of the previously thrombosed deep veins.

Key learning point: Duplex ultrasonography is the first-line diagnostic test for chronic venous insufficiency, as it detects venous reflux and assesses valve competence and vein patency.
questions.hint: This patient's unilateral chronic dull pain, edema, dilated veins in the lower extremity, and history of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) suggest chronic venous insufficiency (CVI).
